resources.string: Authentication Error - Check your username and password.
This email is already in use.
Incorrect email format. Please try again.
Password must be at least 6 characters long.
This username is already in use.
Please check your internet connection or try again later.
Name must have a length between 3 and 10 characters.
Are you sure you want to quit the game?
"Are you sure yo want to cross out\n%1$s ?"
"Welcome to the Dice game!\nThis tutorial will introduce you to the rules of the game, and show you valuable tips that will increase your chances of winning!"
"The aim of the game is to score more points than your opponent. Points are scored by completing combinations visible on the left side of the screen."
"A combination can only be completed once. Once a combination has been scored it cannot be changed, so it is important to think through every move as it can determine the final result!"
"Now take a look at a combinations chart. Remember that you can use it at any time during the game. All you have to do is select 'Combinations chart' in the game options."

"Note that combinations 1 to 6 and Small Street and Big Street require exactly the same values as shown in the list. Other combinations only require specific criteria to be met, in which case the values may differ."
"For example, Full House requires you to roll 3 dice of one value and 2 of another.Both 3 1s and 2 2s and 3 2s and 2 1s meet these criteria."

"Small Street requires dice with values: 1,2,3,4,5 Large Street: 2,3,4,5,6 In both cases the values cannot be repeated. Four of a kind requires 4 dice of equal value. A Five of a kind requires 5 dice of equal value and is the most difficult combination to roll."
"SOS is a specific combination. It has no criteria and can be used with any combination, but only after the last roll."

"It is worth using SOS if after last roll you have not managed to get any combination. You should also consider this step if the score obtained in another combination is very low, especially if we are talking about a combination with much better scoring possibilities."

"For example: if after last roll the only combination you have is a pair of ones (giving 2 points), you should consider using SOS and give yourself a chance to roll a much better pair in the next turns. Remember: like any combination, SOS can be used only once!"

"Let's move on to the rules of scoring. Points are counted only after adding up the dice REQUIRED IN THE CRITERIA OF A COMBINATION. If you roll a pair of 6's, a five, a four and a three, then points for a Pair will be counted ONLY from the sixes. The other dice will be ignored."

"Another thing to remember is the "First Roll Rule". If you finish a combination after making only one roll, the points scored will be doubled! So be careful, because making a second roll can take away a lot of points from the first roll."

"You have 16 turns at our disposal. Each turn consists of 3 smaller turns in which you roll five dice. Remember: usually before the second and a thirdAttention: usually before the second and third roll there are some dice you would like to keep in order to obtain a particular combination. In order to do that, you need to mark the dice you want to roll again."

"Once selected, dice will be surrounded by a purple border. The other dice will not participate in the re-roll. If you want to roll all the dice, simply press the dice roll. You don't need to select them all."
"Enough theory. It's time for practice! Make your first roll!"
"You rolled Fours on the first roll! This means that your points will be doubled. Except in certain situations it is advisable to use the combination scored on the first roll."

"Note that highlighting of available combinations is enabled by default. This can be helpful especially for new players. You can disable this feature at any time in the game options. Now score the Fours!"

"Good! You have scored 24 points. The dice required for the combination have been added up, and since you scored the combination after one roll, the score has been doubled. Let's see what you can roll this time. Roll the dice!"
"You rolled One Pair on your first roll. Hold off on scoring this combination though, as it only gives you 8 points."
"One Pair is the easiest combination to roll and you will certainly be able to roll a much stronger one in subsequent turns. So it is not worth wasting it."
"Let's try to hunt for Twos. You need one more, and you have two rolls in front of you, so the chances are good. Mark all the dice except the twos and then make a second roll."
"This roll has definitely improved your situation! You were planning on scoring Twos, but now you have five combinations available! These moments happen quite often, remember to react accordingly."

"Now let's decide which combination to choose. In a situation where you have many combinations to choose from, it is advisable to choose the one that is the most difficult to roll. In this case, it's Full House. Get this combination!"
"Good. Time to complicate things a bit!"
"As you can see, you have two combinations left to score. You also have an unused SOS at your disposal in case you don't manage to roll either of them. Let's try it! Roll the dice!"
"You need Four of a kind and Five of a kind. So you need to roll at least four identical dice. In this situation you will try the sixes. Mark all the dice except the sixes and roll again."
"Just one more six. Third time lucky!"
"Bad luck. Fortunately, you have unused SOS, so you don't have to cross out another combination. Use SOS."

"As you can see in the case of SOS the points from all dice are counted. Sometimes it is worth considering to cross out a low scoring combination (Ones), or a very difficult combination (Five of a kind), instead of using SOS with low score."
"The situation is difficult. There are three very difficult combinations left. Let us see if you can manage it. Roll the dice!"
"You seem to be lucky! With two unused Streets, this roll is very good. Take a look at the dice. Can you already guess why?"
"In this situation, just roll one of the fours and get one or six. One will give us a Small Street and six a Large Street. Let's try it! Select the last of the fours and roll the dice!"
"It did not work out. Fortunately, you have one more roll. Mark the last of the threes and try again!"
"You managed to roll Large Street! As you can see, your first roll gave you a good chance of success. Remember it so you don't miss it in the real game. Now score Large Street."
"There are only two combinations left. Roll the dice!"
"You need a three for Little Street. Roll the first 2 again."

"Unfortunately not this time. You are left to cross out one of the combinations. Always cross out lowest scoring combinations, or the hardest to roll. In this case, it is the Five of a kind. Cross it out."
"Combination cross out confirmation is enabled by default. It allows you to avoid the mistake of cross out wrong combination. You can deactivate this function in the game options at any time."
"That's the end of training! It's time to apply this lesson in a real game! Before you face a real player, it's worth practising against a computer opponent to avoid losing ranking points."
"You can repeat this training at any time by selecting it from the main game menu. I WISH YOU MANY VICTORIES AND GOOD LUCK!"
